Article.ArticleTitle: Kinetics of the reaction between hydrogen peroxide and aqueous iodine: Implications for technical and natural aquatic systems.

AbstractText: Oxidative treatment of iodide-containing waters can lead to a formation of potentially toxic iodinated disinfection byproducts (I-DBPs). Iodide (I<sup>-</sup>) is easily oxidized to HOI by various oxidation processes and its reaction with dissolved organic matter (DOM) can produce I-DBPs. Hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) plays a key role in minimizing the formation of I-DBPs by reduction of HOI during H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>-based advanced oxidation processes or water treatment based on peracetic acid or ferrate(VI). To assess the importance of these reactions, second order rate constants for the reaction of HOI with H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> were determined in the pH range of 4.0-12.0. H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> showed considerable reactivity with HOI near neutral pH (k<sub>app</sub> = 9.8 × 10<sup>3</sup> and 6.3 × 10<sup>4</sup> M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup> at pH 7.1 and 8.0, respectively). The species-specific second order rate constants for the reactions of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> with HOI, HO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> with HOI, and HO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> with OI<sup>-</sup> were determined as k<sub>H2O2+HOI</sub> = 29 ± 5.2 M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, k<sub>HO2</sub><sup>-</sup><sub>+HOI</sub> = (3.1 ± 0.3) × 10<sup>8</sup> M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, and k<sub>HO2</sub><sup>-</sup><sub>+OI</sub><sup>-</sup> = (6.4 ± 1.4) × 10<sup>7</sup> M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, respectively. The activation energy for the reaction between HOI and H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> was determined to be E<sub>a</sub> = 34 kJ mol<sup>-1</sup>. The effect of buffer types (phosphate, acetate, and borate) and their concentrations was also investigated. Phosphate and acetate buffers significantly increased the rate of the H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>-HOI reaction at pH 7.3 and 4.7, respectively, whereas the effect of borate was moderate. It could be demonstrated, that the formation of iodophenols from phenol as a model for I-DBPs formation was significantly reduced by the addition of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> to HOI- and phenol-containing solutions. During water treatment with the O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> process or peracetic acid in the presence of I<sup>-</sup>, O<sub>3</sub> and peracetic acid will be consumed by a catalytic oxidation of I<sup>-</sup> due to the fast reduction of HOI by H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. The O<sub>3</sub> deposition on the ocean surface may also be influenced by the presence of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, which leads to a catalytic consumption of O<sub>3</sub> by I<sup>-</sup>.
